wordpressPost.title: Don’t be afraid of aging
wordpressPost.content:
Don’t be afraid of aging

Being old was something I was terrified of. Let’s admit it, doors open up for us when we are young. When we’re old, we don’t get the respect we deserve. As much I hated to admit it, it wasn’t the aging that I was running from, it was the fear of the unknown that I could not come to terms with. This is the real obstacle in my aging progression.

I used to be afraid of cancer or a disease that I would die from. Now, after seeing my mother-in-law go from a Friday evening dinner as a relatively healthy and strong women to unable to wake up from a stroke on a Saturday morning, to a nursing home where she could not even feed herself, all within a week or so, made me realize two things:

One, that life is really short so quit living in fear and just start living in the moment, and two, that a nursing home is no place to live. So while we are capable we must use every moment to live and use our bodies.

God sure does show up to teach us just at the right moment; when we are questioning our own existence. In Buddhism they say, “When the student is ready, the teacher will appear.” It’s a sad reminder, and the reality of where we all end up.

I’m not saying anything negative about reputable nursing homes, God bless them, but we all know how depressing they can be.

When I walk in the nursing home I am completely in the moment, deeply grateful and extremely aware of every fiber of my being. I want to run out of there and scream at the top of my lungs about how grateful I am to be healthy, alive, and for the opportunity to walk out of there and be me, the person I have taken for granted lately.

I have the opportunity and the great fortune to leave, and they never will. I feel that I’ve won the lottery of life and they have lost. How beautiful is it to have everything, and to be awakened to appreciate it?

When I walk through the halls to my mother-in-law’s room, I mourn for the people lined up against the walls, left in their wheelchairs to deteriorate until their final day arrives. Seeing it in their eyes as I walk by, while trying not to look into their eyes, I see many wish that that final day will come sooner than later.

I tell myself it’s not fair to get to an age and then be tossed aside. But I know it’s in God’s hands, and I only hope he is taking care of them in his own way,, and I hope they are feeling that he is too.

I see people who were once happy and vibrant, and had the world in front of them as I do now. I realize how close I am to where I will be, and I am stricken with the reality that I better start living with gratitude and appreciation this minute, and not live in a future that may or may not come.

Right now, today is all I have. I need to stop wasting my life fearing my future. I know that one day, I will look back at pictures of my middle-aged self I am so afraid of, and say, “Look how young you really were.”
